Check with your facilities administration before implementing ventilation modifications. ","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"373aa","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":27,"offset":0,"style":"bold"}],"key":"744t","text":"Additional recommendations:","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"5cqoo","text":"If constructing a new space, a laminar flow ventilation scheme for the room is best, as this delivers regular air movement concentrated around the edges of the room, away from the equipment. Otherwise, it is good practice to avoid placing equipment directly underneath vents when planning your equipment layout.","type":"unordered-list-item"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"f8510","text":"Doors should be closed during an experiment or protected by an inside curtain to block drafts.","type":"unordered-list-item"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"4d2c","text":"Appendix 4: Tutorials","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":21}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bnq7p","text":"How to place a power meter sensor on a microscope","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":49}],"data":{}},{"key":"8egag","text":"How to set up a Power Meter for Illumination Intensity Measurement on a Light Microscope","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":88}],"data":{}},{"key":"9luff","text":"Short-term laser stability (using Zen Blue (Zeiss) and Argopower meter (Argolight)","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":2,"offset":0,"length":82}],"data":{}},{"key":"tpdq","text":"Laser Power readings on a Nikon confocal with a Thorlabs Power Meter","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":3,"offset":0,"length":68}],"data":{}},{"key":"dj6bu","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4uhv1","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4gm6j","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"link","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"AF139526B6A811ED9EF70A58A9FEAC02","url":"https://youtu.be/hNou8fRW-e0"}},"1":{"type":"link","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"AF139563B6A811ED9EF70A58A9FEAC02","url":"https://youtu.be/6Sb6zpg-woM"}},"2":{"type":"link","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"F0EAEF3A70CA11EDA1E10A58A9FEAC02","url":"https://youtu.be/xfpIDaRqChQ"}},"3":{"type":"link","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"F0EAEF7470CA11EDA1E10A58A9FEAC02","url":"https://youtu.be/4aO_zXzz5_E"}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"52g9c","text":"Appendix 1: Power meter settings Q\u0026A","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":36}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"e3h4a","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dnbae","text":"Some of the answers below are specifics to Thorlabs' power meters","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":0,"length":65}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9kbi3","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"acsu7","text":"1. How much of the sensor area needs to be illuminated for accurate measurement?","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":80}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6bo65","text":"It is recommended to not focus on the sensor and to keep the diameter of the illuminated area within 1 to 10 mm. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"39kjh","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"63k4f","text":"2. Should I use an immersion medium for my objective when measuring illumination power?","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":87}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3iman","text":"When measuring the power through a high NA objective (NA\u003e1) it is important to check whether the sensor is designed to be used in air or whether an immersion medium should be used between the front objective lens and the sensor. Using an appropriate immersion medium allows the sensor to detect the total laser power over a high NA, without losses arising from deflection or reflection. Most power meter sensors are not water-proof, and can be damaged by exposure to water or oil. However, some sensors were designed specifically for microscopy applications and can accept a drop of immersion media (for example the S170C sensor from Thorlabs). ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9bn47","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4am2r","text":"There will be a difference in power measurements with and without immersion media when the NA of the objective is above 1.1. This is caused by:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"77b50","text":"Total internal reflection (which can be mitigated in the S170C via an index matching gel in between the silicon sensor and the cover window) and/or","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4v520","text":"Absorption of light from the immersion medium (i.e.10% less for water and 15-20% less for oil when compared to air).","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6fu16","text":"","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"24dsq","text":"3. Is the detection linear across the sensor? ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":46}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"vq24","text":"The measured power response may not be linear near the edges of the sensor. Hence, it is important to center the beam to improve linearity but also to avoid clipping the beam on the edges of the sensor. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cp3md","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"72o79","text":"4. How to prevent damage and saturation of the sensor?","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":54}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"e2vfv","text":"Keeping the optical power below the maximum rating in the specification sheet prevents saturating the sensor. Higher powers than specified will saturate the detector or create zones of critical saturation on the sensor, leading to a non-linear measurement of the signal. You can use a neutral density filter to lower illumination power. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5ei31","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1m03r","text":"5. How does the integration and readout time work and what should be the preferred power meter bandwidth settings?","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":114}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7922f","text":"A photodiode has a response time of 1 µs, but the electronics behind it are slower depending on the readout device used. The rule of thumb is to set the bandwidth to \"low\". For very fast fluctuation measurements, it is best to use a very fast photodiode with an oscilloscope rather than a power meter, power meters being designed for slower changes (see Figure 3, Lower panel, H).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"c2pr0","text":"Very different speeds also require the usage of different photodiodes. When a photodiode converts photons to electrons, the flow of electrons out of the sensor is governed by its capacitance. Thus, large photodiodes, with high capacitance, are poor at detecting fast dynamics, but their large area makes it easier to capture the light beam, especially when it comes out a microscope objective with a low NA or when no objective at all is used. For fast dynamics, you will need a smaller photodiode, which has lower electrical capacitance and responds faster, and you will need electronics designed to sample quickly as well. For this, a high-speed oscilloscope is preferred.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3hhn1","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"17u67","text":"6. Does the power meter need to be calibrated or just the sensor?","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":65}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"59cqe","text":"The power meter does not change over time, thus, only the sensor needs to be calibrated regularly. Calibration data is typically saved in a chip in the DB9 (red) connector of the sensor for Thorlabs power meters. Other vendors may store this information elsewhere. We recommend checking the calibration status of your sensor by comparing the results to those obtained with a different sensor.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2q2j5","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7e80c","text":"7. How often does a power meter need to be calibrated?","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":54}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9ddi4","text":"It is different depending on the power meter you use, but typically the measurement accuracy may change by 2-3% over 3-4 years but could also deviate by up to 10% over a longer time. In general, it is recommended to calibrate a power meter yearly. However,  if you are not exceeding the specified power rating, a calibration should be stable for 2-3 years. This is within the wavelength range of 300 to 1060 nm; shorter wavelengths may incur further deviation.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fo5cg","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cttto","text":"8. Is using a power meter safe?","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":31}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dvpv","text":"For standard confocal microscopes, it is generally safe to take power meter measurements but before you do so, make sure you check with the vendor or the person who built your system. Also, check your organization’s regulations around laser safety, as they vary by country and jurisdiction. Precaution regarding the reflectivity of the coating of the sensor should be taken. Up to 0.5-1.5% reflection may occur when delivering high powers to the sensor. You can damage your eyes using a power meter through stray reflections from a significantly powerful lamp or laser, and you must be trained to carry out this procedure using eye protection, when necessary. Under no circumstances should you check high-powered lasers such as those used in multi-photon systems, TIRF systems, or point localization systems without training.Typically, less-reflective thermal sensors are used with a higher power as they have higher maximum power ratings and are designed to measure such lasers.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"25gbg","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5obgr","text":"9. Can you capture the data and change settings on a computer?","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":62}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9952q","text":"If your power meter uses a standard Universal Serial Bus (USB) to a Common (COM ) terminal you can send Standard Commands for Programmable Instruments (SCPI) to the power meter and query data and other parameters. For example, the PM400 (Thorlabs) allows for different capture intervals to the internal memory via SCPI commands. Most common programming languages support serial terminal commands so writing a simple program to query the power meter from a personal computer is often straightforward. Some power meter consoles also support storage media such as a removable USB drive or Secure Digital (S.D.) card which can log data for later review.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9t3i9","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ce8nk","text":"10. How to calculate the photon flux from power measurements?","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":61}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3je54","text":"The number of photons (n) observed per unit time (t) is the photon flux (Φq). ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5pp7v","text":"Formula:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"UNDERLINE","offset":0,"length":8}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4afog","text":"Photon Energy:     Ep=hc/λ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3n646","text":"Measured Power: Pmeas=n∙Ep/λ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"di5dg","text":"Photon Flux: Φq=n/t=Pmeas/Ep=Pmeas∙λ/hc","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1tm2c","text":"(c =3∙10^8 ms and Planck constant h=6.62607015∙10^−34 Js)","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bo040","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"43jq1","text":"11. Are there different types of power meter sensors?","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":53}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dmqcm","text":"Yes, three different types: photodiode, thermal power, and pyroelectric energy sensors.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ai5eq","text":"Photodiode sensors have a strong spectral sensitivity dependence and must be calibrated over the entire wavelength range. On the other hand, they have a high dynamic range (70dB), very low noise, and high response speed. Photodiodes are made of different semiconductor materials like silicon (190-1100 nm), germanium (400-1700nm), and indium gallium arsenide (800-2600nm). They are common for low-to-medium power measurements typical of visible light confocal microscopes.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"UNDERLINE","offset":0,"length":18}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"29kin","text":"Thermal power sensors use the Seebeck effect that turns heat flow into a power-proportional voltage. They can be used up to very high-power levels. Their useful dynamic range is much lower than the range of the photodiode sensors (30dB). Another drawback of the type is that they are very sensitive to ambient temperature or airflow (drafts). Hence, they should be shielded from moving air during measurements. In general, the speed of response is low. Therefore, a few seconds of settling time is often required","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"UNDERLINE","offset":0,"length":21}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dvqcv","text":"Pyroelectric energy sensors can only handle pulsed signals (no continuous wave). A pyroelectric crystal converts the heat impact of a laser pulse into its energy-proportional voltage. They are more commonly used for high energy, lower repetition rate pulse lasers which are not common in microscopy except for certain photo-activation and microsurgery applications.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"UNDERLINE","offset":0,"length":27}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3d2a8","text":"","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7ci37","text":"12. Using the same type of sensor, will all power meters give me the same values?","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":81}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dq5bd","text":"Yes, most of the time. However, different values can be observed between different models of power meter sensors due to the sensor's calibration, electronics, and composition (a sensor without gel filling the gap between the filter glass and sensor surface will show lower power levels with high NA objectives). ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"egfj5","text":"Different values can also be obtained when measuring broadband light sources. Different detectors or filters have different spectral curves, which can run in opposite directions. Since you can only set one wavelength point from the entire incident light spectrum, the light outside the wavelength set point gets weighted differently and causes the difference in the reading.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1jho8","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"c7mv2","text":"13. Do different light sources (e.g., laser, LED, lamp) require a different type of sensors?","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":65},{"style":"bold","offset":66,"length":26}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"hneb","text":"Thermal sensors best measure broadband light sources, such as white lamps, as this type of sensor, is not wavelength sensitive.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"br1i1","text":"Narrower-band light sources, such as filtered lamps, lasers, and LEDs can be measured with photodiode sensors but the accuracy of the measurement will depend on the bandwidth of the source. Most lasers and LEDs are narrow band enough that the error will be negligible, but some broadband LEDs (phosphor type without a bandpass filter) may be more accurately measured with a thermal sensor if sufficiently powerful. If a photodiode is used for a broadband light source, the error may be compensated for by considering the wavelength response of the photodiode, as discussed above.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7s6kg","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2pbg2","text":"14. Is the electric grounding of a power meter essential?","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":10},{"style":"bold","offset":11,"length":46}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5vgc5","text":"Power meters typically filter interference from nearby electronics or power cords. For very sensitive measurements, or particularly electrically noisy environments (rare), additional measures may be necessary (like grounding your sensor). It is also preferable to use the power meter in battery-operation mode (unplugged from wall power) as this will isolate the meter electronics from any noise coming through the power lines.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cobhs","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"el7rk","text":"15. Is zeroing the power meter at each wavelength important?","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":60}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"et5qt","text":"The zeroing feature measures dark current (if the sensor is covered and is not detecting ambient light), and subtracts it from future measurements. It is not wavelength dependent. Therefore, you can simply do it once when you switch it on.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6k742","text":"The zeroing feature can also be used to compensate for room lighting by performing the “zero” sampling with the sensor uncovered, but the light source to be measured shuttered or blocked. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"blbmg","text":"After zeroing, keep the room light settings constant during your measurement.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"52thb","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"an9f4","text":"16. How to measure the pulsed input and peak power of your light source?","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":72}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1u89o","text":"You need a fast response/reacting power meter (like the new Thorlabs PM103) and sensor, or a pyroelectric energy sensor for these measurements. For microscopy applications, typically only some fast-flashing stimulation or uncaging light sources require these types of measurements. If the power meter response speed cannot follow the pulses, you will get an average measurement as the sensor will average the effect of the pulses over time in its reading.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ckh5r","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dbjk4","text":"17. How can circularity, shape, and diameter of the beam affect the measurements?","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":81}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3hfau","text":"The power reading (Watts) should not be affected by the shape and diameter of the illumination spot except when the illumination spot overfills the sensor or is focused so tightly on the sensor that it creates local variation or saturates the sensor area (this can damage the sensor). It is best to have a defocused illumination spot, as mentioned in Question 1.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"77tfg","text":"The power per unit area (usually W or mW per cm2) is impacted by the illumination spot's shape, intensity profile, and diameter. If the geometry and profile parameters of the illumination spot are known, they can be used to calculate irradiance (mW per cm2) once the overall power in Watts is measured.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3aadg","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"c5jeb","text":"18. What does \"averaging\" exactly do?","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":37}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2q2a7","text":"Depending on your chosen settings, it averages the results of multiple readings, reducing measurement noise. For example, if you set the power meter with an average of 100, it will take 100 readings and report their average. Note that averaging slows down the speed of measurement, as the meter must acquire all the readings to be used in the average before performing the average and displaying the result, although most meters are fast enough that 10s or 100s of readings for an average is not excessive. (Figure 3F)","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2gen1","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4la7p","text":"19. How to measure Broadband Light Sources?","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":43}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4rs3h","text":"Every sensor has a wavelength-dependent responsivity (see Figure 8). To achieve a correct power measurement, the current or voltage measured by the power meter must be multiplied by the responsivity factor of that sensor at the illumination wavelength used (if the power meter model used does not do it automatically).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":58,"length":8}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6d9lc","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5ck9i","text":"When using lasers, this operation is directly taken care of by the power meter once one has entered the laser wavelength into the power meter (Figure 8a). If not, to do the calculation without a power meter, just take the measured current or voltage measured by the power meter and divide it by the responsivity value at your laser wavelength from the calibration certificate of your sensor. Ex:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":143,"length":9}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"80hd5","text":"Power  = I / R(λ) for photodiode sensors","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":0,"length":17}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"c5sh6","text":"Power = V / R(λ) for thermal and pyroelectric sensors","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":0,"length":16}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"b49mn","text":"with I being the current and V the voltage measured.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":5,"length":1},{"style":"italic","offset":29,"length":1}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"aj0qv","text":"For example, using the responsivity curve shown in Figure 8a, if the current measured at 830nm is 3mA, the power is 3[mA]/0.52[mA/W]=5.77[W].","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"avhf7","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bsp87","text":"For broadband illuminations, like LEDs or other lamps in combination with excitation filters, one must take into account at least three important parameters that may influence the absolute power measurement: the spectrum of the light source, the specifications of the excitation filter and of the dichroic, and the responsivity of the power meter sensor (see curves in Figure 8b). However, to make the measurement easier and robust, WG1 agreed on a convention: the wavelength to be set on the power meter should be in the middle of the bandpass of the excitation filter. Note that if the measurement is done within the linear range of the responsivity curve of the power meter (Figure 8), using the center of the bandpass is a way of averaging responsivity values. The specific spectrum of the light source within the excitation bandpass should not have any significant influence on a biological experiment, and is not getting further consideration here.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":369,"length":9},{"style":"bold","offset":678,"length":8}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"chtdf","text":"For the measurement and calculation of power from the current or voltage value, proceed as for lasers above. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"biv5j","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6a6v4","text":"The measurement has to be done for every channel (i.e., a combination of LED/laser and filter set) used.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"b1te2","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5mnu5","text":"In the case where a multi-band pass excitation filter is used, the wavelength set on the power meter should in the middle of the band-pass region matching the LED used.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"apro6","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ct9o5","text":"There are thermopile sensors that are designed to measure light power of light sources with a bandwidth of wavelengths. For the width of bandpass filters and powers typically used in light microscopy the predicted divergence  of thermopile sensors form the above proposed method are expected to be moderate. (From Thorlabs/M. Gonnert: There will only be a negligible deviation (~1%) between thermal or photodiode sensor for narrow bandwidth (\u003c1nm) light source. For low power levels (\u003c100 mW range) the photodiode will always deliver more stable readings and lower noise levels, although thermal sensors with sub-microW resolution exist.) Thermopile sensors are also not sensitive to the entrance angle of light.
